docs.lead_paragraph: CONWAY--Alvin J., was president and chief executive officer of Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens and Director of Health and Hospitals for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn for 25 years, 1970-1995. Under his leadership, the Catholic Medical Center became the largest voluntary health care provider in New York, and one of the largest in the United States. CMC comprised four hospitals and three longterm care facilities, which included a total of 1,695 beds and the largest hospital based home care program in the country. During Mr. Conway's presidency, four hospitals were remodeled or replaced and 18 Family Health Centers were established in medically undeserved areas of Brooklyn and Queens. In addition, the School of Nursing, as well as schools for emergency medical service technicians, radiological technicians and laboratory technicians were organized. CMC also included a substantial substance abuse program. Mr. Conway also oversaw businesses as diverse as a "captive" insurance company, a Medicaid managed care program and the Kennedy Medical offices at JFK International Airport. Before his tenure at CMC, Mr. Conway served as executive director of Knickerbocker Hospital in New York City (1960-70) and as administrative assistant at Roosevelt Hospital in New York (1954-60). He was named President Emeritus of the Catholic Medical Center (now St. Vincent's Catholic Medical Center) upon his retirement. He received a BA in management at City College of New York and an MS in hospital administration at Columbia University. He served with the Army in Europe in the Second World War. Mr. Conway was a consultant and lecturer to professional groups and health care organizations in the United States, Europe and the Far East. He was past president of the New York State Catholic Healthcare Council. He participated in various state and national policy groups, including the House of Delegates of the American Hospital Association and the Regent's Advisory Council of the American College of Healthcare Executives. Mr. Conway's publications dealt with diverse issues of health care administration including the future of the multi-hospital system and an article on the career of the physician-pope, John XXI. He was a Life Fellow of the American College of Healthcare Executives. In 1995, he was awarded the B'Nai Birth Distinguished Achievement Award for his lifetime of accomplishment in health care and the Samaritan Foundation bestowed its annual award to him for outstanding achievement in administration. Mr. Conway was named Fellow of the Year of the New York American College of Hospital Administrators in 1985. Mr. Conway was the beloved husband of Gail of Tarrytown, NY and the devoted father of Jimmy (Barbara) of Goshen, NY; Jack (Jo Ann) of Albany, NY; Susan (Timothy) of Yorktown Heights, NY and Christopher of Denver, CO, and the loving grandfather of Jesse, Brian, Rebecca, Kyra, Cory, Kieran, Cassandra and C.J. Visiting Thursday, May 8, 2008, 7-9pm, Dwyer Funeral Home, 90 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health officials in China, responding to the continued spread of hand, foot and mouth disease, issued new regulations requiring all health care providers to report new cases of the disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: Local governments and state universities cannot offer health insurance to the partners of gay workers, the State Supreme Court ruled. The court ruled 5 to 2 that Michigan’s 2004 ban against same-sex marriage also blocks domestic-partner policies affecting gay employees at the University of Michigan and other public-sector employers. The decision affirms a February 2007 appeals court ruling. Up to 20 public universities, community colleges, school districts and local governments in Michigan have benefit policies covering at least 375 gay couples.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tennessee plans to cut 2,011 state jobs, mostly through voluntary buyouts, to shore up the state budget and save about $64 million each year, the governor said.
